text: Patient: Well, this only started when I… Doctor: Yeah, so you know… Patient: I’ve been having pain in my back but I had that. That’s when my back was hurting then right after that it was found out that I the cancer and they went ahead so. Doctor: Right, yeah, so we’ll just follow to make sure it’s nothing new, anything new that pops up and of course you’re getting the CAT scan because I want to make sure there’s nothing new in the liver or the lungs or anything as well. I’m not expecting it to but we have to check. Now, if your PSA is just, you know, creeping up, which it kind of is, I know. Patient: It went up. Doctor: Yeah, it did, it did. You’re actually at, wait, you were…. Patient: I was at 19. Doctor: You were 19 and you’re like at 42 I think Patient: Wow. Doctor: so that’s a hint that uh-oh something’s happening. So, we’ve got 2 options because I’m going to assume that your scans might show something is, maybe 1 or 2 new spots or something. Not drastically worse because you don’t look it. You don’t, that’s not how you are. Certainly, you’re better than the first time I met you. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, you’re in better shape, better control, but we have to get early, you know, we have to get an early jump on this. Let’s say the cancer is back or it’s worse. Well, you had that run of chemo so we’re not going to repeat that but other options would be, we actually have 3 studies to consider Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue that you run the risk is if it does show up and we'll catch it early or you're aware of it and it pops up in your lung. Patient: Yes, that’s not good. Doctor: That's something that can be associated with pain or sudden death. Patient: Right. That's right. My sister in law died of that. Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like.

text: Patient: Right. text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A mitosis means however the cell’s dividing. And you have like the very lowest mitotic rate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your gist basically it’s it’s a really dumb one; it doesn’t really know how to metastasize. So when you’ve got a cancer, you’d rather have a dumb one than a smart one. You had a really dumb gist tumor. But you’ve kind of got a smarter prostate cancer. So the gist tumor I think is extremely unlikely… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …to spread to a lymphnode although it is theoretically possible. But what is far more likely given the fact that you have a prostate cancer with you know high Gleason score and a PSA that is rising… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum.

text: Patient: Now is it possible to get the pre and/or post treatments at a local or local - Healthcare Professional: The draw? Patient: LabCorp or Quest or something? Doctor: Yes, absolutely. Patient: Okay. ‘Cuz I don’t mind comin’ down obviously, but if I can shave a couple hours out of a day- Doctor: Yeah. If you on a Monday, went over to LabCorp, got your blood tests, awesome. Tuesday, we clear you, and if you want Wednesday or Thursday to be your chemo day, you just tell me. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, then and so, all that works from a time frame. Then, the counts, the next week which you’re getting - I don’t know if that’s for the study or - then you can get that at LabCorp. That’s gonna come to us. Uh, we don’t do much with that. That’s more if you call us, and you say, “Hey, you know, I have a fever.” We can look at those blood tests and say, “Hey, it’s low. So, you should go to the hospital.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, it’s normal. You’re like everybody else. Just take your Tylenol or whatever. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, and we’ll get you a chemo teaching class.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So, a lot of times, they don’t let us move up. Sometimes they let us move up if the next guys have tolerated it well. Patient: And showed improvement or something like that? Doctor: Um, uh, yeah, that would be tough. And if they were benefiting and you weren’t, maybe higher dose – I don’t know what the rules are. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But, oftentimes they don’t let us increase the dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But some protocols do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So those are just nuance of that type of escalation. Uh. You --- it would be a window. So, it would be something that again if you’re trying to avoid chemotherapy, here’s something that I could try. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s, uh, uh, the third option of a trial, so, is chemotherapy plus vitamin C, a phase one study. The other study would be that we would have to check a blood test on you, uh, that if you came back as AR-V7 positive. And I’d have to see if we’ve already done that for you in the past.

text: Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, man, no, we don’t take out anywhere close to your entire blood volume. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just like this much but to do that they have to sort of strain for the right cells. That’s why you’re hooked up to this machine that they have for like two and a half three hours. So, I always say, you know, bring something to read. They play movies. If you have to pee a lot, you bring a urinal so you don’t have to get up because if nurses will start screaming if you move and um there’s two ways. Like you have pretty good veins so um most of the time they can just do it straight from your veins. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They’ll tell us whether that’s possible. A bunch of other people you need a port for six weeks where they actually put it in your arm or your chest and they remove the stuff, you know, out and then when we’re done we pull it out. Now, go like this and you know that your veins are there. They’re not spectacular veins but I don’t think they’re terrible veins. So, it’s like three hours for us to do that procedure and then when you get it reinfused back on a Thursday this stuff comes back in a bag and you get it through Patient: mm hmm.

text: Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
